title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Piece of evidence

· New phenotypes

· Different DNA sequence

· New genotypes

· Chromosomal differences

· Different mRNA sequence

· Protein with different amino acid sequence
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the available points.

Piece of evidence

· New phenotypes

· Different DNA sequence

· New genotypes

· Chromosomal differences

· Different mRNA sequence

· Protein with different amino acid sequence

Student response earns one of the available points.

· New phenotypes

· Different DNA sequence

· New genotypes

· Chromosomal differences

· Different mRNA sequence

· Protein with different amino acid sequence

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Describe mechanism

· Sexual reproduction produces offspring with new combinations of alleles/traits

· Meiosis produces new combinations of alleles/traits

· Crossing over produces new combinations of alleles/traits

· Independent assortment produces new combinations of alleles/traits

· Random fertilization produces new combinations of alleles/traits

· Immigration/gene flow introduces new alleles/gene sequences

· Viral infection inserts DNA into genome

· Nondisjunction causes anomaly in chromosome number

· Chromosomal rearrangements (e.g., large deletions, duplications, translocations, inversions, transposons, etc.) inactivate genes or result in multiple copies of genes

· Radiation or chemicals or mutagens induce mutations/changes in DNA

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Description

· Genetic variation is the basis of phenotypic variation that can be acted upon by natural selection

· Without genetic variation, there is no phenotypic variation on which natural selection can act
